summary: This document is an email chain from November 14, 2019, between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel, forwarding news articles about the Epstein estate's plan to establish a victims' compensation fund and new lawsuits filed against the estate. It discusses the estate's retention of Kenneth Feinberg, objections from some victims' lawyers, and details of three new lawsuits filed by accusers, including allegations against Ghislaine Maxwell and mentions of Alan Dershowitz.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure whose estate is the subject of lawsuits and a proposed compensation fund for accusers. He died by suicide in August 2019 while facing federal charges.

persons.name: Kenneth R. Feinberg
persons.context: Retained by the Epstein estate to set up a 'claims resolution program' to pay accusers.

persons.name: Camille Biros
persons.context: Tapped to help set up the claims resolution program; an architect of programs for Catholic Church abuse scandal victims.

persons.name: Jordana Feldman
persons.context: Tapped to help set up and carry out the claims resolution program; played a role in the September 11 Victims Compensation Fund.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Filed a court document stating his client does not believe alternative dispute resolution should stay litigation against the estate.

persons.name: Roberta Kaplan
persons.context: Objected to the estate's compensation plan being developed without consulting accusers, calling it 'a continuation of his crimes and abuse after his death.'

persons.name: David Brodie
persons.context: Expressed cautious optimism about a resolution program but raised concerns about the process exacerbating victimization.

persons.name: Bennet Moskowitz
persons.context: Hired to handle lawsuits by accusers; did not respond to requests for comment on the proposed program.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.role: Executor of Epstein's estate, Epstein's longtime lawyer
persons.context: Named as an executor of Epstein's estate and a defendant in new lawsuits filed by accusers.

persons.name: Richard Kahn
persons.role: Executor of Epstein's estate, accountant for Epstein's companies
persons.context: Named as an executor of Epstein's estate and a defendant in new lawsuits filed by accusers.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Filed three new lawsuits against the Epstein estate and represented accusers in litigation against Alan Dershowitz.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Accused of procuring young women and underage girls for Epstein and participating in abuse. Named in new lawsuits.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Represented the Farmer sisters in litigation against the Epstein estate and previously represented an accuser in a case against Alan Dershowitz.

persons.name: Matthew Goldstein

persons.name: Tom McParland

connections.description: Described as companions; Maxwell is accused of procuring girls for Epstein and participating in abuse.
Indyke was Epstein's longtime lawyer and is now an executor of his estate.
Kahn was an accountant for Epstein's companies and is now an executor of his estate.
Feinberg was retained by the Epstein estate to set up a claims resolution program for accusers.
Boies's firm represented an Epstein accuser in a defamation suit against Dershowitz; Boies later sued Dershowitz for false accusations.
Dershowitz is described as visiting Epstein's mansion, though he disputes the timing and nature of visits.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide at the Manhattan Correctional Center while facing federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: Dismissal of Criminal Indictment
events.description: Federal prosecutors dismissed the sex-trafficking indictment against Epstein after his death.

events.title: New Lawsuits Filed Against Epstein Estate
events.description: Three new lawsuits were filed in Manhattan federal court by Epstein's accusers, represented by David Boies's firm, alleging battery and intentional infliction of emotional distress.

events.title: Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty in Florida state court to soliciting prostitution from a minor, derailing federal prosecution. Court filings estimated he had sexual activity with at least 30 underage girls.

events.title: Meeting with U.S. Attorney's Office
events.description: Representatives from the U.S. attorney's office in Manhattan met with some of Epstein's accusers and their lawyers to discuss the ongoing investigation into potential accomplices.

locations: U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Epstein's estate, valued at about $577 million, is considering a 'claims resolution program' overseen by Kenneth Feinberg to pay accusers, but some victims' lawyers object to the process.
Three new lawsuits were filed against the estate in November 2019, with allegations dating from 1995-2002 and implicating Ghislaine Maxwell in procuring and participating in abuse.
The lawsuits reference Alan Dershowitz visiting Epstein's mansion when young girls were present, though Dershowitz vehemently denies any wrongdoing or being there at the time alleged.
Epstein's 2008 Florida plea deal estimated he had sexual activity with at least 30 underage girls, a fact referenced in the context of potential claims against his estate.
Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are continuing to investigate potential accomplices of Epstein following his death, as indicated in meetings with accusers' lawyers.
